item.title: A bowhead whale's DNA offers clues to fight cancer
item.description: Scientists searching for new ways to combat cancer think they may have uncovered a promising new lead in the DNA of the bowhead whale.

item.description: In an essay in The New Yorker, Tatiana Schlossberg says she has acute myeloid leukemia. She also criticized her relative, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: Why do we get goosebumps? A podcast tries to answer science's surprising questions
item.description: Hakeem Oluseyi, host of NOVA and GBH's podcast Particles of Thought, breaks down how his show tackles some of science's biggest and strangest questions.

item.title: U.N. climate talks end without agreement on phasing out fossil fuels
item.description: Dozens of countries had called for a clear "roadmap" to transition away from the use of coal, oil and natural gas. The U.S. did not participate in the negotiations.

item.title: Brain scientists are seeking weight-loss drugs without the nausea
item.description: Weight-loss drugs like Wegovy and Zepbound often cause nausea and other side effects. Brain scientists are looking for ways to solve this problem.

item.description: Officials say a fire that spread through pavilions being used for U.N. climate talks in Brazil has prompted evacuations on the next-to-last day of the conference.

item.title: 'Nightmare Obscura' author explains how to take control of your dreams
item.description: Sleep scientist Michelle Carr has spent years researching dreaming. She explains dream engineering, including how sensory inputs like light, sound and vibration can influence the subconscious.

item.title: Eating just a handful of plastic can be fatal for marine animals, a study finds
item.description: Scientists have long known that plastic waste is bad for marine animals. A new study quantifies how little ingested plastic it takes to be a lethal dose.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Trump administration seeks to roll back protections for imperiled species and habitat
item.description: The Interior Department proposed reviving a suite of changes to Endangered Species Act regulations first made during the Republican's first term. Those changes were reversed under former President Biden.

item.title: How a twangy voice can help you be heard
item.description: We usually associate twangy voices with our favorite country singers. Now researchers from Indiana University found that twangy voices do project better over noise.
